articles.headline: In Alabama Race, a Test of Business Efforts to Derail Tea Party
articles.snippet: Business groups like the U.S. Chamber of Commerce are pouring money into a special House primary runoff that is seen as a test case for the fight over the Republican Party’s future.
articles.abstract: Business groups like the U.S. Chamber of Commerce are pouring money into a special House primary runoff that is seen as a test case for the fight over the Republican Party’s future.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOBILE, Ala. — With only days to go before a special Republican primary runoff for Congress here in South Alabama, the national business lobby is going all in.
articles.byline: By Campbell Robertson and Eric Lipton

articles.headline: Angry Over U.S. Surveillance, Tech Giants Bolster Defenses
articles.snippet: What began as a public relations predicament for American technology companies has evolved into a moral crisis that threatens the foundation of their businesses.
articles.abstract: What began as a public relations predicament for American technology companies has evolved into a moral crisis that threatens the foundation of their businesses.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Google has spent months and millions of dollars encrypting email, search queries and other information flowing among its data centers worldwide. Facebook’s chief executive said at a conference this fall that the government “blew it.” And though it has not been announced publicly, Twitter plans to set up new types of encryption to protect messages from snoops.

articles.headline: When Insurers Drop Policies: Three Stories
articles.snippet: Insurance companies are canceling millions of health insurance plans that fail to meet minimum standards, and a look at the stories of three people with such plans tells a complex tale.
articles.abstract: Insurance companies are canceling millions of health insurance plans that fail to meet minimum standards, and a look at the stories of three people with such plans tells a complex tale.
articles.lead_paragraph: Charles Nance, Dean Wright and Julie Tyrrell are getting dropped — forced out of their existing health insurance plans — and landing smack in the middle of the uproar over President Obama’s health care law.
articles.byline: By Katie Thomas and Reed Abelson

articles.headline: Troubled Start for Health Law Has Democrats Feeling Anxious
articles.snippet: Democrats say that the law’s woes are cutting into the momentum they gained after the government shutdown, and that the troubles could cost them in the 2014 midterm races.
articles.abstract: Democrats say that the law’s woes are cutting into the momentum they gained after the government shutdown, and that the troubles could cost them in the 2014 midterm races.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Already under fierce attack from Republicans over the new health care law, President Obama now faces broad and mounting Democratic concerns that the troubled start of the insurance program will cut into the political benefit the party received from the government shutdown and cost Democratic candidates in next year’s midterm elections.
